insights.insight: Ad tech charges $5–$150 CPA for probabilistic attribution; this protocol settles at ~$0.10 per verified receipt — a 50–200x cost difference rooted in structure, not optimization. The receipt is the conversion event, not a model of one.

With Chrome deprecating cookies and device fingerprinting increasingly blocked, the industry's primary cross-site signals are gone — and first-party data is blind beyond a single brand's ecosystem. Verified, identity-free receipts fill a gap that no current stack addresses.

Visa and Mastercard see merchant category codes and transaction amounts, not line-item detail; Apple and Google data is ecosystem-locked and identity-attached. This protocol produces cross-merchant, cross-category purchase signals without attaching identity — a combination that does not exist elsewhere in market.

Three new metro areas (CBSAs) activated in a single snapshot — a 21.4% diffusion rate described as the highest recorded — suggesting physical commerce coverage is expanding in discrete pulses rather than gradual linear growth. For brands running regional campaigns, this is the metric to watch.

At 3,436 receipts across 14 categories — grocery, pharmacy, big-box, SaaS, home improvement, and more — the dataset is small but structurally diverse, meaning basket overlap and category co-occurrence analysis is already possible before the network reaches mass scale.

Receipts accumulate whether or not a brand queries the protocol — meaning competitors can analyze a brand's customer overlap and retention patterns while that brand sits out. The dominant strategy for any brand is to participate; opting out does not remove their receipts from the dataset.
